The reason is the potential for miscarriage. Some pregnancy massage experts argue that pregnancy massage doesn't, in itself, cause miscarriage, but no research has been done to show a link between a massage and a miscarriage. Because many miscarriages happen in the first trimester, some massage therapists and doctors counsel against first-trimester massage simply to avoid any potential liability issues should a miscarriage occur.The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine advises all pregnant women to consult with their doctor before trying massage.

question: How can doing exercises make bed rest easier?
response: Do the exercises your doctor recommends. You need to keep up your muscle strength. Moving your legs will lower the risk of blood clots.

question: How is mechanical dilation done to induce labor?
response: With mechanical dilation, your doctor or midwife triggers labor with a balloon catheter. At the hospital, your doctor inserts a thin tube through your vagina into your cervical opening. Then the doctor uses water to inflate the balloon at the end of the tube, causing your cervix to expand.

question: Will you feel sick if you eat your placenta?
response: If you research online or talk to women who have tried it, you can get varied opinions. Most women who want or expect to feel good or better after eating placenta do, though that may be just a placebo effect. Some women have said they feel sick after eating it. Those are based on personal experience, not scientific evidence.Swallowing a pill with the dried placenta might be easier if you're squeamish about seeing, touching, or tasting the "raw" tissue itself.

question: What happens to your baby's growth during month 2 of pregnancy?
response: Your baby's facial features continue to develop. Each ear begins as a little fold of skin at the side of the head. Tiny buds that eventually grow into arms and legs are forming, along with fingers, toes, and eyes.The brain and spinal cord are well formed. The digestive tract and sensory organs begin to develop. Bone starts to replace cartilage. The embryo begins to move, though you can't feel it yet.By the end of the second month, your baby is about 1 inch long and weighs about 1/3 ounce.

question: Do I need iron supplements if I am pregnant with twins?
response: Taking an iron supplement can help ensure you get enough iron every day. In most cases, you will get enough iron in your prenatal vitamin since many types contain the recommended amount of iron. Your doctor will check your iron levels periodically depending on your test results and if you are a vegetarian.) If your iron level is low, you may need to take an extra iron supplement.

question: Is it okay to exercise in the heat when I'm pregnant?
response: On hot summer days, plan ahead so you can exercise in the cool of the morning or evening, or find a gym that has air conditioning. Steer clear of Bikram and other forms of hot yoga while you're pregnant. Make sure you drink plenty of water. Be sure and check with your doctor before starting an exercise regimen.

question: When should you call a doctor about pregnancy test results?
response: If you get two different results from pregnancy tests, call your doctor. A blood test is a good idea to confirm results.

question: When should I get a quad marker screen?
response: Between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy, your health care provider may offer you a quad marker screen. The test can only be performed during the 15th and 20th week of pregnancy.

question: What is a maternal-fetal medicine (MFM) specialist?
response: Maternal-fetal medicine (MFM) specialists are also called perinatologists. These doctors have special training in handling complicated and high-risk pregnancies.

question: What are symptoms of a false pregnancy?
response: Women with pseudocyesis have many of the same symptoms as those who are actually pregnant, including:Interruption of the menstrual periodSwollen bellyEnlarged and tender breasts, changes in the nipples, and possibly milk productionFeeling of fetal movementsNausea and vomitingWeight gain

question: How long does labor take?
response: First-time moms are usually in labor for about 12 to 18 hours, on average. If you've had a baby before, labor usually goes more quickly, usually about half that amount of time. Childbirth is a unique experience for every woman, every time. Sometimes, the baby comes really fast. Other times, well, not so fast. How quickly your baby arrives depends on many things.

question: Why is it common to have back pains during pregnancy?
response: You could have back pain during pregnancy because of the extra strain on your back and belly muscles or changes in your posture. Heat or cold packs or massage often help.

question: What is hyperpigmentation and is it linked to pregnancy?
response: Hyperpigmentation is a darkening of the skin and is caused by an increase in melanin, the substance in the body that is responsible for color (pigment). Pregnancy causes excess melanin production.

question: How is gonorrhea treated during pregnancy?
response: Pregnant women with the infection can be treated with antibiotics. Because gonorrhea is often without symptoms, all newborn babies are given medications in their eyes at birth to prevent development of the gonorrhea eye infection.

question: What can severe or untreated iron-deficiency anemia in pregnancy lead to?
response: Severe or untreated iron-deficiency anemia during pregnancy can increase your risk of having:A preterm or low-birth-weight babyA blood transfusion (if you lose a significant amount of blood during delivery)Postpartum depressionA baby with anemiaA child with developmental delays

question: What does a midwife do?
response: Like a doctor or an OB, a midwife can provide care before, during, or after your pregnancy. Your midwife will:Provide family planning and preconception careDo prenatal exams and order testsWatch your physical and psychological healthHelp you make your birth plansAdvise you about diet, exercise, meds, and staying healthyEducate and counsel you about pregnancy, childbirth, and newborn careGive you emotional and practical support during laborAdmit and discharge you from the hospitalDeliver your babiesMake referrals to doctors when needed

question: How common is trisomy 18 in babies?
response: Trisomy 18 is the second most common type of trisomy syndrome, after trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). About one in every 5,000 babies is born with trisomy 18, and most are female. The condition is even more common than that, but many babies with trisomy 18 don't survive past the second or third trimester of pregnancy.

question: What are fundal height and fetal heart tones? I'm pregnant with twins.
response: Fundal height is the height of your uterus. At each visit, your doctor will check this. It helps verify the babies' growth.Your doctor will also check the babies' fetal heart tones. She can probably hear two separate ones using a handheld ultrasound device.

question: What do genetic tests look for?
response: The tests look closely at your DNA for genes that are linked to certain diseases. Standard screening tests check for:Cystic fibrosisFragile X syndromeBlood disorders such as sickle cell diseaseTay-Sachs diseaseSpinal muscular atrophy

question: What is the quad marker screen?
response: The quad marker screen is a blood test that predicts the likelihood that a woman is carrying a baby that has a birth defect. This means that for some women who have healthy babies, screening results will show a possible problem. And for some women, birth defects in their babies won’t be detected.Since quad marker screen results can be uncertain, you can opt to not have the test. Talk to your doctor about the pros and cons of taking this test before you decide.

question: Is movement in your abdomen normal during the second trimester of pregnancy?
response: By the midpoint of your pregnancy (20 weeks) you will probably have started to feel the first delicate flutters of movement in your abdomen, which is often called "quickening." If you aren't feeling your baby move yet, don't worry. Some women don't experience quickening until their sixth month of pregnancy.

question: What is uterine bleeding (postpartum hemorrhage)?
response: After your baby is delivered, excessive bleeding from the uterus, cervix, or vagina -- called postpartum hemorrhage -- can be a major concern. Excessive bleeding may happen when the contractions of the uterus after delivery are impaired, and the blood vessels that opened when the placenta detached from the wall of the uterus continue to bleed. Other things like cervical or vaginal lacerations can also cause uterine bleeding.

question: What ## intent:faq/s should you ask about a pregnancy health care provider who's in group practice?
response: Will I see every provider with whom you rotate during my doctor visits? Do I have a choice about who I see and who delivers my baby? (If you choose a doctor who belongs to a group practice, usually all the members of the group will see you during your pregnancy and one of them will be there for the delivery.)Whom will I see at each appointment?Note that there are no guarantees that a specific health care provider will deliver your baby since no provider is available 24 hours a day; make sure you know the other providers in the practice or the providers with whom the doctor shares delivery responsibility.

question: How does your pediatrician work with your delivery team?
response: Most hospitals ask if you have a pediatrician when you go in to deliver. Your baby's first examination may be with a hospital pediatrician or your chosen pediatrician. It depends on the hospital's policy and whether your newborn's doctor makes rounds there. If a hospital pediatrician checks your baby, they'll send your pediatrician notes about the exam.After you leave the hospital, your pediatrician will see your baby 48 to 72 hours later, and regularly after that for checkups.

question: What is diastasis recti?
response: Diastasis recti means your belly sticks out because the space between your left and right belly muscles has widened. You might call it a pooch.

question: Can you exercise if you are pregnant with twins?
response: Talk to your doctor.  Some twin pregnancies come with complication and risk -- others don't.If you are at high risk for complications, your doctor may recommend that you put your exercise plans on hold until after your babies are born. Or, he or she may suggest that you cut back on exercising at around 20 to 24 weeks.If your doctor gives you an OK to exercise, make sure to learn what types of exercises are best to avoid. T

question: How do you check your cervical mucus?
response: To check your cervical mucus:Keep in mind that other things, like breastfeeding, can change your mucus. Using douches or other hygiene products can also affect it. Gynecologists usually don't recommend these products.Use your fingers or a tissue to check the opening of your vagina for mucus a few times a day. Make sure your hands are clean before you start. Write down whether it's cloudy and sticky or clear and slippery.Chart your cervical mucus changes and your basal body temperature to get a clear picture of where you are in your cycle.
